the methodology of the london attacker fits into a a pattern of behaviour which we have we seen for which we witnessed in in tease last year on france is national day and again in berlin shortly before christmas with the transformation of of a vehicle

everyday object into a weapon against the softest of targets people like us going about their daily lives posing no threat to anybody what we already knew before this latest attack is that the terrorist threat remains extremely high across europe an attack which finished at the uk parliament

is an attack on our democracy and i think that that is felt and a shared understanding right across the european union those who carry out these attacks want to target our way of life target our values but we are not going to let them we in

that is why i believe that france was right to go ahead with the euro two thousand and sixteen championships last summer even after the attacks in paris and in nice and i think it was right the decision in december of the german authorities to keep their christmas markets open

all be it with extra security measures there is never going to be one hundred security there is never going to be zero risk but we can and will continue to make further attacks as difficult and therefore unlikely as we can

i do believe that we are making progress in that effort our collective shared efforts to bear down on the space in which terrorists and o those who wish to do us harm operate and our shared efforts to build our resilience but we need to keep we need to keep going and what we are discussing today is one aspect of that continued work
thank you becoming the opportunity to say a few words on that let me move on to the subject on the agenda you suggested that we use this session to discuss information sharing instruments

a key part of the architecture of reinforcing our collective security and i welcome the opportunity to do that at your request we provided you with some background information as you just mentioned and i understand that you had a productive exchange with special experts the other day
as threats are becoming more complex so cooperation and information sharing also becomes ever more important to help reinforce our citizens security

it is only together that we can tackle the multiple threats from from terrorism but also organised crime and cyber attacks as we have discussed before i am completely convinced that the first step is to make full use of existing legislation and initiatives to promote information exchange amongst all the actors in the field of security

that is why the commission has constantly called on member states to exploit fully the potential of existing information systems at eu level and we are working steadily to support member states in this with funding with expertise and sharing best practice

the commission has worked hard to tackle this challenge over the last couple of years in april two thousand and sixteen as you know we set out a strategy on information systems for borders and security that analyse existing eu information systems identifying shortcomings and gaps and setting out actions that could be taken to address those

better implementation and use of eu information systems is one of the pillars of our work towards a stronger and smarter set of information systems and interoperability we already had a chance some of us to discuss the state of play on information exchange during during a plenary discussion in february but for those who were not there let me just briefly recap

the state of play on the existing systems first the schengen information system this as we all know is the most widely used information share ing system for law enforcement in europe it is i believe a real operational success and i note that it is use by member states is growing year on year

in two thousand and sixteen the competent national authorities check persons and objects against data hold in the sis on nearly four billion occasions that is an increase of forty use compared with year before two thousand and fifteen the number of hits increased from around one hundred and fifty zero in two thousand and fifteen to more than two hundred zero in two thousand and sixteen

that said i think there is still rum for technical and operational improvements to make this more effective and efficient and that is why the commission has presented a set of legislative proposals and so more about that in a moment

our agency eu lisa is working within the current legal framework on technical improvements to the sis notably the introduction of an automated fingerprint identification service affice that would allow border guards and law enforcement officials to search the system by using finger for inte

material with that it will be possible to identify people in a more reliable manner and to detect persons travelling under false identities and the aim is to roll at out in a pilot form for six member states by the end of the year

the commission has also supported initiatives to increase awareness raising activities in member states and i think that has helped to lift the number of checks and increase the use by national services of the sis
if you if you take a site longer perspective there has been an eight hundred increase in the number of discreet and specific check alerts issued by national security services in the last two years

secondly the the prum decisions as you know an important tool in enhancing cross border cooperation in acted in two thousand and eight providing for the exchange of data regarding dna fingerprints and vehicle registrations

the deadline for implementation by member states was august two thousand and eleven five member states still do not comply with the prm decisions the commission launched infringement proceedings in last september we have received replies from all five member states and we are currently in the process of assessing them before taking decision on next steps

it in parallel the commission supports member states to make full use of rum through funding and facilitating the exchange of best practice third the so called swedish initiative which as you know provides a common legal framework for the exchange of information between member states good progress has been made in its implementation but there are still differences in the way member states use this instrument

we are carrying out an assessment of compliance to get an overall picture and we will then decide on what further steps might be useful to ensure full application by all member states fourth council decision two thousand and five six one on the exchange of information on terrorist offences

this as you know requires member states to transmit relevant information to europol eurojust and other interested member states and less that would jeopardise ongoing investigations these obligations have just been strengthened by the adoption of the directive on combating terrorism

i would like to take this opportunity to thank again the european parliament and especially this committee for the work they have done on this file which i believe will significantly contribute to strengthening our security fifth the visa information system

i also helps in safeguarding member states internal security since september two thousand and thirteen law enforcement authorities have had access to this data basis this database on the basis of a specific law enforcement decision an evaluation found that in practice access to the vis for law enforcement purposes is still fragmented across member state

turning to our agencies we have made substantial progress in the last two years on information sharing with europol and eurojust for instance the number of foreign terrorist fighters communicated to europol and therefore entered into the europol information system has more than doubled since december two thousand and fifteen reaching seven and eight hundred and eighty four entries in january this year

just to be clear that includes both eu citizens and third country nationals this is the result of increasing trust in europol systems better understanding of their operational value and the robustness of their data security

seven the eu pnr directive agreed by all but as we have discussed before not yet fully implemented as you know member states have until may two thousand and eighteen to implement the directive to support that work the commission presented an implementation plan last november with guidance and best practices

the commission has held dedicated meetings on workshops and we will provide funding and offers of a dedicated platform for practitioners on lessons learned we are also about to adopt an implementing decision on data formats and transmission protocols that air carriers should respect when transmitting pnr data to member states authorities

let me now turn that the legislative initiatives the commission has presented to address the gaps that were identified in our april two thousand and sixteen strategy the commission presented three proposals in december to improve and extend the use of the schengen information system

these proposals will contribute to ensure an effective exchange of information between member states to fight cross border crime and terrorism and improve borders and migration management notably for the first time we proposed to make it obligatory for member states to issue alerts in sis for persons related to terrorist offences

we also proposed to make the introduction of entry bans for third country nationals compulsory in the sis to strengthen the enforcement of such bands the proposed regulations also strengthen data protection by introducing additional safeguards in line with the reformed eu data protection rules
these are now with you and the council for discussion and all be happy to work closely with the rapporteurs to take this work forward with you

other proposals on the table concern the reform of the asylum databased your adacq to further enhance its functionalities as regards irregular migration and return and the extension of the european criminal records information system to convicted third country nationals on the lat of the commission will present a modify proposal in june

let me say a few words on the proposal for an eu entry exit system which will register the crossing of the schengen external border by third country nationals i believe it will improve our security as it will tell member states authorities which travellers enter move around within and leave the schengen area

and it will contribute to fighting terrorism and serious crime by supporting the identification of suspects and perpetrators as well as their victims i welcome the progress that has been made by the rapporteur mr di as the mere and this committee on the proposal and look forward to that work coming to a successful conclusion

finally let me turn to our proposal for a european travel information and authorisation system ts it will allows to assess the security and irregular migration risks of visa exempt third country nationals before they travel to the schengen area

by spotting problematic individuals and preventing them from coming the system will enhance european security as agreed by the institutions in the joint declaration the proposal is a legislative priority and should be therefore adopted before the end of the year and i will be very happy to support the rapporteur mrs gill in efforts to take this work forward
it has been suggested that the work on ets depends on progress made in the discussions on interoperability but i wanted to say to you this afternoon i am not sure that is right

the commission presented the ets proposal in november last year to address an important information gap on visa free travellers and that information gap requires urgent action to help secure our external borders ets as a self standing instrument will help close that gap irrespective of our parallel work on interoperability

because of the urgent need to act on ts the commission made use of the exemption not present an impact assessment i know some of you raised questions about that but we did base our proposal on a comprehensive feasibility study that was published together with the proposal

it is because of the urgent need to close the information gap that all institutions agreed to make ets a legislative priority in the joint declaration so the work we are doing on interoperability does not need to and should not put on hold important work on the proposals that are currently being discussed by the co legislators

including ts the eu entry ectricate system and the proposals for reinforcing the sis it does not affect or delay the work on these information systems that we need in any case and that will we will continue to need whatever we subsequently decide together to do on interoperability

which brings me to my last point our work on interoperability to better connect information across our information systems last time i was in this committee in late january i was very happy to discuss with you the interim findings of the high level expert group on information systems and interoperability the group we set up to assess different options on interoperability

it continues its work and will present a final report in early may with findings and recommendations following that and in line with our ipa two thousand and sixteen strategy the commission plans to present some concrete ideas to you in parliament and to the council in mid may as the basis for a discussion with you on the way forward
